title: Modern humans Out of Africa – Southern coastal route
desc: Homo sapiens likely dispersed along the southern Arabian coastline into South Asia and onward to Southeast Asia/Australasia (~70–50 ka).
harvard_refs: Pagani, L. et al. (2015) Tracing the route of modern humans out of Africa using 225 genomes from Ethiopians and Egyptians. AJHG, 96, 986–991.
Bae, C.J., Douka, K. & Petraglia, M.D. (2017) On the origin of modern humans: Asian perspectives. Science, 358, eaai9067.

title: Neolithic farming expansion into Europe
desc: Anatolian early farmers spread agriculture into Europe through two routes — a northern Danubian and a southern Mediterranean path.
harvard_refs: Haak, W. et al. (2015) Massive migration from the steppe was a source for Indo-European languages in Europe. Nature, 522, 207–211.
Mathieson, I. et al. (2015) Genome-wide patterns of selection in 230 ancient Eurasians. Nature, 528, 499–503.

title: Steppe pastoralist expansion across Eurasia
desc: Pastoralist groups from the Pontic-Caspian steppe spread eastward and westward, transmitting both language and subsistence systems.
harvard_refs: Allentoft, M.E. et al. (2015) Population genomics of Bronze Age Eurasia. Nature, 522, 167–172.
Damgaard, P. de B. et al. (2018) The first horse herders and the impact of early Bronze Age steppe expansions into Asia. Science, 360, eaar7711.

title: Peopling of the Americas
desc: Ancient genomes reveal migration from Siberia across Beringia into the Americas during the late Pleistocene.
harvard_refs: Raghavan, M. et al. (2014) Upper Palaeolithic Siberian genome reveals dual ancestry of Native Americans. Nature, 505, 87–91.
Moreno-Mayar, J.V. et al. (2018) Early human dispersals within the Americas. Science, 362, eaav2621.

title: Copper Age steppe migration: Proto-Indo-European dispersal
desc: Migration of a steppe/Caucasus population ~6.5 ka spreading Proto-Indo-European languages and steppe ancestry across Europe and Asia.
harvard_refs: Harvard Medical School News. (2025) Ancient-DNA study identifies originators of Indo-European language family. Nature, 2025.

title: Migration & interaction along coastal Papua New Guinea
desc: Human migrations and admixture along the coastal regions of Papua New Guinea inferred from ancient DNA, diet, and linguistic data.
harvard_refs: Nägele, K. et al. (2025) Ancient DNA analysis reveals regional migration patterns and local interactions in coastal Papua New Guinea. Nature Ecology & Evolution, 2025.

title: Early Medieval migrations across Europe (6th-8th c AD)
desc: Large-scale migrations from Eastern Europe into Central Europe in the Early Medieval period shown by ancient DNA (>80% ancestry replacement).
